comment_text:
When I was a kid my Dad would take me with him when he would "moonlight" and measure parts for people using Coordinate Measuring Machines (CMMs). I have one particular memory of him programming a CMM while I was looking at a book we got from the library of the drawings of Leonardo Da Vinci. I've always thought he has a wonderful way of describing complex phenomena and try to mimic his teaching techniques as best I can. I'm very proud of my Dad, and grateful to have been able to make this video with him.

I'm also very impressed with the incredible work so many people did to make the James Webb Space Telescope happen. The amount of brute force brainpower that went into making it happen is INCREDIBLE. I dream of a day when we all work together as humans to dare mighty things and work on them together.

Thanks for watching Smarter Every Day. It means a lot.

Here's the link to the fun JWST shirt if you're interested. I wanted a shirt that had the maximum amount of JWST talking points. L2 Orbit path, sunshields, mirrors.... It's awesome. I commissioned an artist named Penny from the UK to design the graphic for the shirt and we're really happy with how it came out! Here's the link: https://www.smartereveryday.com/store . I'm not a merch guy, I just genuinely think it's cool and thought you might like to have one.

This is cool! I used to use a Faro and Inca 3 for setting up bonding fixtures and contour measurements of a reflector shell for a Space Satellites. We had thousands of targets on the surface of the reflector shell. The SMRs had us achieve tight tolerances at 2.5 true positions. I love working in the Aerospace/Defense Industry. Your experience with your Dad reminds me of my own experience. My Dad, his sister and his brother turned me on to high tech in my formative years. My Dad worked (for Boeing) as an aircraft maintenance/modification technician, and was part of a unit that did maint/mod work on the aircraft that is used an Air Force One here in the states, as well as the elite aircraft from a few other countries. My uncle worked (for IBM) an an electronics technician in assembling the instrumentation ring that was part of the Service Module for the Saturn 5 missions of Apollo that went to the Moon. My aunt was part of the engineering team that did flight tests for developing the B-52 aircraft.  As for me, I ended up working (for Martin Marietta) as an Engineering Development Technician,  on the CCMS <checkout, control and monitoring subsystems> for the Space Shuttle program. I had a pretty small part in the shuttle program, but lemme tell ya, when the first Shuttle launched with Young and Crippen, I cried like a baby, cuz I had a very small part in getting that first flight off the pad

Dustin, I may have an answer for you that you asked @9:30. I at one time worked in the Energy Efficiency industry as a sales manager where we manufactured and sold radiant barrier ("RB") for residential and commercial applications. Radiant barriers work in two ways. They both A) reflect thermal radiation, measured in a 'reflectivity' scale from 0-100% and B) resist the transference of radiation through an object, referred to as emissivity, again measured from 0-100%. A RB that reflects 97% of thermal radiation only "emits" 3%. Reflectivity and emissivity are inverses of one another. For an object to be accurately called a radiant barrier (for marketing purposes) they must reflect at least 90% or more of the radiation (or emit less than 10% of the radiation) that the object absorbs. Reflecting happens on the side of the RB that faces the sun. The emissivity action happens on the side the RB that is not facing the sun. A RB MUST, MUST, MUST have an air gap on one side of the film. If you 'sandwhich' the RB between two things you neutralize the efficacy of the RB as the thermal radiation will just 'conduct' through the RB. Thus, along those lines, a critical factor that will degrade the reflectivity/emissivity of the RB is whether or not you put a film one one side of the RB, say a silicone coating perhaps. But, as long as the other side of the RB is clean and shiney and exposed by at least a 1" air gap, the RB will function via its emissivity properties as opposed to 'reflecting' - which I imagine is why they have the shiney side on the inside, away from the sun. The silicone is probably there to help reduce photo-degeneration that will happen over time.

What is interesting is that in space, the radiators actually ARE radiating, not conducting as "radiators" on Earth do to lose almost ALL of their heat: by passing it to the air or something else. The truest test of how effective a radiator is at actually radiating heat is how well it works in a vacuum.

Also, the "cooling fins" employed on items in the atmosphere would be counterproductive and stupid in a vacuum, where thermal radiation is leaving a body and needs to have an unobstructed path to its discarding reflector or to deep space. Any fins that face at other fins (like most finned heat sinks on Earth) are heating those other fins with radiation.

Thus, the ideal radiator in space has as much surface area as possible normal to the nearest route that gets the heat radiated to the nearest "exit" aka deep space.

Law enforcement where there's a budget for it use the FARO to scan accident scenes.  Our old 3D scanner often took 2-3 hours to scan because it required a lot of scans.  The new FARO system is much faster and much more accurate.  This helps the fidelity of the case that can have significant affects on people's lives.  Many accidents happen as a result of cold weather where you're exposed in the elements and sometimes exposed to danger.  Having a machine like that is a significant boone for safety in that you can capture every scrap of data you need for later and then open a road back up, or let people go about their lives again quickly without sacrificing accuracy.  When you mark the locations of pertinent details, such as skid marks, clothing, liquids, marks, holes, debris etc. you can solve for speeds, direction of travel, and better model what happened in a more conducive environment to concentration.

This was very touching to watch. All the technical science-y stuff was extremely interesting and informative, but there at the end, watching you and your dad watch the launch and seeing the emotions play across his face actually brought a tear to my eye.

It's too easy, out here among the "common folk" to hear about something like the James Webb Telescope launching and putting nothing more than a passing thought to it before we go about our normal routines. To delve deeper into someone's story, someone who literally spent years of their life hyper focused on just one part of the process, really sheds light onto just how much goes into something like this.

I can't imagine spending such a long time, dedicating so much to make certain that my project is absolutely perfect, then watch as they pack it on top of a rocket and launch it out into space in a series of events where any minor mishap results in absolute failure. I now understand just a little bit more just why mission control erupts into celebration at the completion of a successful launch and deployment.

Thank you for sharing this unique view; not just the technical side but the personal side also.

If I were to guess, the heat shield is likely a dark color to maximize heat loss through black body radiation; I’m not a part of the project so I can’t say for sure the reasoning. Essentially, black/dark colors are better emitters of black body radiation, so at high enough temperatures you achieve better cooling performance from energy loss through black body radiation rather than attempting to reflect the photons in the first place.
This isn’t within my own field of physics specialization though, so feel free to fact check me or pipe in if you are more knowledgeable on the subject.

I worked for a swimming pool maintenance company when i was younger.. We used to measure for loop lock or merlin safety covers (anchored winter covers that you can walk across) and we used an A B measurement process. We'd set 2 points either 10 or 20 feet apart (depending on the size of the pool) and make a shitload of marks around the pool and measure from A then B the distance to each mark on the pool perimeter (or waterfall or rock formation or ladders and stuff). Same idea as this, but a little less sophisticated. : )

Fun fact. In the construction field when you see a curved archway on a building or house we use the catenary curve to mark those archways. The blueprint will give us the width and the height of the archway in the center. To mark this on the plywood we set the sheets on edge mark the ends and center hight of arch then we use along peice of beaded light switch chain and hang it between the points and adjust in and out until it touches center mark gravity gives us a perfect curve. Then you just spray over the chain with spray paint and when you pull the chain away it leaves a perfect curved line to cut. Good stuff.

This was a joy to watch, especially the launch. You may cover this in another video, but the main principle at work here is exemplified by MLI (multi layer insulation).
The first layer reflects most of the light/heat but what little is absorbed gets re-radiated: half away, half inward to the second layer.
The second layer reflects most of this light/heat but what little is absorbed gets re-radiated: half back out to the first layer, half inward to the third layer and so on.
At equilibrium in space, each successive layer (and the object they are shielding) is colder than the last.

I grew up watching man take the first steps into space, land on the moon, and became absorbed in all things about outer space/travel. I like many children and young adults at the time dreamed of being an astronaut. Well, life happens along the way and focus shifted. Even so, my enthusiasm to keep abreast of all new space-related activities became a part of my life. Now as I stretch out on the proverbial Lazy-boy in my later years, I still yearn for all things space. I believe another historic space-related milestone is still within my lifetime. Not sure what it is yet. But hearing your personal connection and in-depth knowledge about the JWT has made me pause and wonder, could the JWT provide that one historic space milestone. Could it be Elon Musk and SpaceX with the incredible strides they've made to revolutionize how we travel to space and make those sci-fi movies growing up actually become a reality. You and your father's story have made me feel like that starry-eyed dreamer kid so many years watch in amazement as human-changing events were within my grasp. Thank you for this incredible story/lesson on what is within our grasp right now. I get caught up in the intricate details of how this project all came together. Now I feel it's once again it's within my grasp to be able to witness yet another part of space history in my lifetime. Great job on pulling this video together, and thank you for sharing it with us.
I can't wait to see the incredible data we are going to get from this awesome feat of engineering.  Projects like these restore my faith in humanity :)

By establishing a particular shape, the shield guide can "persuade" the infra-red energy along a particular path and thus shoot it out the edges of the shield -- this makes the shield massively more effective and nearly removes the need for a heat-sink.

I've seen several of your videos before and a channel subscriber now. Your dad and the gentlemen working with him remind me of the wisest and most inspiring people I worked with in mathematics and a long telecom career. They've seen and know more in their field than anyone younger but can still talk about it with optimism and the possibilities of things to come. The things people like you and your friend bring forward. Anyone they teach becomes a collaborator more comfortable to take on new knowledge where a know-it-all senior teacher would create just the opposite environment. They tell us what the shape tolerance requirements are sounding casual about things. When asked a "what if" question as any analytical person would do hearing + and - tolerance, they respond with something like "well it better be right...". On any scale, Kilometer, meter, cm or thousands of an inch, we know they are hitting it dead center measuring, marking or punching. I doubt the work your dad retired from would have ever caused him to think he would be qualified and a real contributor to the most important space, time, physics, astronomy, signal-boosting wireless receiver, recorder and retransmitter ever built so far in mankind's history.

Your production teaching moments showed several times in this content but the best moment for me was you starting to explain how the video outtake with your friend the data cruncher was part of a longer timeline. How from the viewers vantage point, we had jumped ahead in time and you were directing as back to content already in progress. It wasn't clear whether your friend instantly got that final-cut editing context and you had already related the Webb's overall purpose (capturing the universe's oldest light) to his slightly sarcastic question about whether you were working with a time machine. Reminding him, your dad yourself and your viewers that a first of its kind time machine (let's call it turbo chilled telee) was truly at hand. I don't know how you accumulated all the content to release it at such a relevant time, both at the LaGrange point and on Earth's always waring surface but watching you sit with you father watching the telescope's T minus launch with the selfie photo you knew had to be taken from the rim of the shield fresh on our minds - PRICELESS. Your camera focused and unapologetically capturing verbal and non-verbal communication from your father as he watched something so important approaching the moment it would achieve it first orbit sustainable orbit. Watching as his six year graveyard shift contributions and so many other people's contributions handed off to the heavens, the operators and potentially future or potential Nobel prize discoverers.

I don't know your dad obviously but the emotions around that launch, the opportunity, his contribution and Webb's possibilities seemed both freeing and overwhelming during that post-launch moment. A father who teaches the son and then gets taught while still being listened to and understood. A son teaches his own kids in the style that worked so well for him (and me) creates content so kids can forever know and brag about a grandfather's accomplishments. Father and son who can be in each other's presence, potentially tearing up with no flinching, no embarrassment and likely no apologies (unless you edited one out). That is what I saw. I learned a bit more than I knew already about the Webb telescope today but the fact that I already knew it was in space cooling down allowed me to experience the amazing mentoring, respect and loving relationship you and your dad have over the long haul. Even if your dad doesn't spend too much energy remembering the you that didn't want to hear about sine functions on days he was teaching them - that speaks volumes.

I'm certain your dad knows it was impossible for any family member to get access and walk around the fifth and final heat shield. The deadline was arriving to take it out of Alabama forever. I was reminded of a time coming across a content channel where a guy was boarding a nuclear submarine over arctic ice flows carrying personal video equipment where top secret methods and operations would be harder to hide from someone with your mind and background. Your dad and people like me don't need to know how you got permission for any of these places but we thank you for what you teach us and for the trust you've more than earned - whether inventorying cleaved moon rocks , diving below sea and surface level or watching something that literally was laid before you flying toward its home beyond the moon. Even Covid helped this video as I would have otherwise seen the contamination suit you and dad wore as something ruining an otherwise, one-of-a-kind selfie. Visitors to Covid 19 Earth know that selfie was perfect. As Microsoft used to say, Is this a great time or what?

As a young boy, and as a young adult, I always had a desire to visit my dad at his workplace to see what he actually did for a living.

I'm now old, retired, my dad has long passed, and the only three things I knew about my dad's career were as follows:

1) He worked inside of a windowless building, which was built inside another windowless building, and the entire facility was behind tall fences with guard shacks.

2) Only "authorized" visitors were allowed on the premises, and there was a small, separately fenced visitors parking lot.

3) My dad NEVER discussed or defined his work.

Once, I asked my dad what he did for a living, and his response was...
"I work in the defense industry, please don't ask again, and let's leave it at that."

A cosh curve (or catenary curve) is a very good structure for self supporting structure.
The curve if you turn it so the turning point is up, like an arch. The forces under gravity, perfectly directing the forces through the curve into the bottom, making it self supporting.
This can be seen in the St Louis Arch, which is a Cosh curve.

Yeah, it's cool that five layers, at five angles, directs the energy produced by working electrinics away from the sensitive measuring device.

What we miss out on, for thirty-five minutes is that the shading from the Sun is the easy part and that the difficult part is solving the coexistence of a radio transmitter / receiver and a detection device.

The more powerful the information collecting and transmitting devices, the more potential interference with the measuring equipment and more attention to relecting / isolating is necessary.

This is so cool. Im a Field engineer for a construction company and we use a laser scanner just like this to do As-builts (basically tolerance tests on what has been built). It locates itself with the same spheres. For more precise measurements and layout, we use a total station which works the exact same way as a laser tracker. We use reflector prisms both to locate the instrument with control points and to perform layout. Pretty cool to see the same kind of instruments being used for taking readings on the building of the James Webb telescope.

Very cool Dustin.  You gave me a really cool flashback when you talked of you growing up with your dad.  When I was a kid (6th-12th grade) my dad worked at NASA-JSC.  He was an analytical photogrammetrist and was developing techniques for for 3D mapping the surface of the moon for the Apollo landing location.  I got to see the cameras Apollo used and he taught me how to use a surveyor's level.  I recall one weekend when we went out to the "Rock Pile" - the simulated lunar surface they had at JSC and I was responsible for running the level and recording the measurements while he ran the pole.  This established "ground truth" data that he had not seen.  The next week he went up in a helicopter and took photos then brought them back and performed calculations from the photos to calculate the numbers I had measured that weekend to prove the technique worked.  SO COOL.  BTW I am an Engineer now and so is my oldest son.

I just wanted to say thanks Destin for all you have shared with us.  Your pride in your dad and your passion are inspiring.  My adult kids and I love your vids.  I am grateful for all you share with us.

As someone who has spent a big chunk of his working life in physical science laboratories, coupled with my academic studies, I've always felt very at home with metrology. There's something indescribable about it.. well, it's the 'precision' in precision engineering isn't it? It's a beautiful branch of the engineering sciences and this is a great example of it.
Which brings me to a couple of questions which I'd really appreciate if you could ask your dad for the answers to?
Firstly, what forms the reference point for all the measurements? I assume it is the floor. Did it have to be poured with precision?
Secondly, (and I have to admit to being a fully-fledged European here)..when your dad made reference to measurements, he was using Imperial measurements. Is that simply because the audience for this video is expected to be largely American? I can't believe that this would be carried out using anything other than metric scientific notation?
Anyways, this was a eally enjoyable video and please pass on my congratulations to your dad for his work, because it was clearly perfect - as the deployment of James Webb telescope demonstrated.

How do they take into account the force of gravity? The force of gravity varies around the world to such a degree that it is incorporated into ballistic equations currently in use for rockets and artillery, right down to sniper rifles. When they use very small weights on a balance beam type of device to tension the shield, does the force of gravity at the test location factored into the tension that will be necessary at the L2 LaGrange Point?  Or is it a moot factor as the tension of the shield is only a measurement in determining it's form factor or shape? Is gravity a force relevant only to mass, the shield's mass being relatively small enough not to matter?  But the shield is also being affected by the solar wind and how does that affect its station-keeping at L2? Thank you, all. My Dad was with Engineering and Development at Clear Lake Houston facility from the beginning of the Gemini program thru Apollo until he retired just before the Challenger exploded on takeoff. He used to travel around to facilities making sure everything was being done correctly and solving problems. I have great memories of parties held every month or so where NASA people and their families would gather at our house for BBQ or shrimp / crawfish boils and socialize... And a huge amount of communication happened where programs were planned and problems were discussed and solutions generated. I saw that they got more accomplished at some of these events than at the job! And the talks and atmosphere being around these REAL Dreamers who really had the bug was intoxicating. I was allowed to hang around these great (mostly men) and listen but I knew to keep my mouth shut, haha.
So in a way I get how you must feel too, we didn't actually do the things but still were so excited and proud to be on the edge.

If you'd like to see a great example of catenaries at work scroll through some images of sailboat race sails.  Search images for "carbon sail" and you'll see them.  The sailmakers lay down the fibers along the catenaries so the load from the three points is optimally distributed.  It helps the sail maintain the foil shape.  Especially when its gusty (the sail doesn't deform).

Your Father and the other measuring technicians did more than measure, they were innovators and creators. They were also humble. And they all had a fabulous sense of humour. The comradery between them is inspirational. And one of the men was your Dad! The chap that used the data your Dad gathered said it all, the technicians did the important stuff, their data gave him something to work with, and the quality and accuracy of the measurement data was the key thing. You Dad was critical in the main function of the sails - the measurement's they took enabled others to determine if the shade was going to work. Your Dad and the others also were critical with the sails not blowing up as the rocket gained altitude by locating the precise locations for the vent holes. And your Dad humbly said many times "I am just the measurer", smarter people do the other things. You and your family have every right to feel proud about your Dad, and so should he!

Because of this video I finally truly realised how huge the value of collaboration between many people with different skills and interests is. Of course you know it to a certain degree because it's taught to you and you realise that "many hands make light work", but it goes further than just scaling up to make the work lighter: it is actually essential to have all these people with different fields of expertise all these different specialists who are simply incapable of doing each other's job to make a immensely complex project like this reality. It's impossible for any one person to accomplish even if they had an eternity to do it.

I think it's very important to realise to that degree that we need each other and need to work together to actually accomplish great things. It should be something we keep in mind while learning and growing and working on ourselves: that collaboration is the optimum. That being a part of a collaborative effort is the place where you can achieve the greatest things.

Its really interesting that this is using a Faro scanner and Spheres - and it was made 2 years ago. Every scan back then needed Spheres. The software is now good enough that you don't need the Spheres anymore, you can merge point clouds without the Spheres. Now, for extremely accurate measurement, you still want to use the Spheres, but its neat to know that LIDAR has improved so much you don't need the reference points anymore for most uses (NASA equipment not included).

My wife uses those same Faro scanners in her work. They use them in crime scene investigations to record a crime scene as is to use in the court room later. Since the scenes aren't clean rooms with fixed data points, her software is able to stitch the scans together using similar dimensions, like the length of a wall. They can then add annotations and information points like where a piece of evidence was recovered, where bullets impacted and their trajectories, and pictures taken on scene. Then the jury in the case can use virtual reality goggles to put themselves in the scene for better reference.

I know the video took 1 min to talk about measuring the spheres with 7 points, but I spent the rest of the video trying to work out why it's 7 with a handheld corner reflector.
Each measurement gives you 6 equations: 1 for distance light traveled, 2 for direction, 2 for the offsets of the reflected light (from hitting the reflector) and 1 for requiring the reflector touching the sphere.
Each measurement involves 5 unknowns: 2 for rotation of reflector, 3 for position of reflector.
4 noncoplanar points gives you a sphere, so I have no idea why it's 7.

33:46 - the whole point of such precise measurements of the SHAPE in 1G at room temp VS 0G with the huge temperature gradient and cooling management they're trying to achieve.
It's not just a shade, it's a channeled set of radiation vanes with a specific curve to maximize radiant cooling.

So cool and informative, learned a little bit about metrology. A few people have described a little about the challenges of metrology to me before, but this really brought that together for me. Recognizing that the layers of the shield are used to guide the heat out the sides explains why they needed such precise measurements on each layer to make sure it matches the model, each layer acts as part of a light guide along with the layer on each side of it. Venting the heat out the sides, especially if you can do that in a relatively balanced fashion, minimizes any forces that would tend to move the telescope.
I'm a total JWST geek but I never knew that the heat radiated horizontally that way between the layers!!    Totally worth my patreon $$$ !!!

comment_text: Kind of an emotional video for me. My dad, grandpa and his three brothers (uncles) were all engineers. They all went into upper management with engineering requirements. One uncle was president of a large railroad company who went into space engineering when his wife died. He worked with the military on the development of ceramics maglev, magnetic levitation. I remember the first time I knew my dad was pretty special. He started designing "gunnery" in WW2 and then worked for awhile designing and building industrial machinery. One day he came home with a telescope tripod he designed and manufactured at work. You can go into the stores and buy one today but not like this one. It was a beautiful thing and worked like a fine clock. I spent many wonderful hours talking and working with these members of my extended family. They are all gone now but not forgotten. RIP

Destin, it's the second time I hear you say JWST will be "behind the Moon". But I wonder if there is not a confusion here. There is an L2 point for the Earth-Moon system, that is indeed behind the Moon. But JWST is at the L2 point of the Sun-Earth system. It's nothing to do with the Moon. Once in a month, the Moon and JWST will be in complete opposite directions.

I've actually had the opposite problem with laser scanners. I don't want the object at a 90 degree angle because I need to find out minute details at 3 meter distance from the scanner and still see objects up to 20 meters away. Therefore I need the pulse to be fairly strong to see that far. The reflectivity is too high when the scanner is at a 90 degree angle. That causes the object (with my SICK LMS511HR scanner) to seem a 1-2 millimeters too near to the scanner for some reason. Even a slight tilt from 90 degrees is enough to circumvent the issue.

I'm operating a CMM at work as I type this. A Zeiss Contura G2 to be specific.

I wish I had the same opportunity with my own dad. My father (Terry Steudlein) was an inspector with Lockheed Martin at the NASA Michoud Assembly Facility for over 20 years. Originally he worked for Chrysler and Boeing during the Saturn V days where the Saturn 1B booster was produced for Skylab. He rejoined with Martin Marietta during the early Space Shuttle days and worked from the 80's to early 2000s when he retired. The assembly facility built the external fuel tank and was shipped via barge to Florida for integration with the shuttle.
He passed away in 2009. I have several memories of sitting in the parking lot waiting for him, and once or twice coming into the main office. However, I was never able to see exactly what he did since it was in "the cleanroom". I wish I could go back and experience that first hand and ask him questions about his work. He was a very private man and never really talked about his life. I often wonder what he would think about the current state of the space program (with companies like SpaceX, Rocketlab, etc.), and the SLS development that is now happening at Michoud.

It was fascinating for me (but in some way also funny) to watch your video about accurate position surveying being a land surveying engineer myself in the UK for more than 13 years now. I use laser scanning in my work (Leica, Faro, and Trimble) and your Dad's explanation why to use two separate tools to gain more accuracy was spotless. It convinced me he is in fact an expert in measuring. For a really accurate reading you cannot rely only on one tool and one measurement. Every tool has an accuracy limit but also the environment differ between measurements (temperature, expansion, flexing etc). In carpentry it was called measure three times before you cut. Just one little note (azimuth is not left and right it is a vertical angle). Thanks for this very educational video, I will show it to my 10y old to make her understand what her Daddy is doing.

What I was able to connect this too is GPS. The spheres around the room are fixed points just like we have on earth. Satellites send out a radio signal. Fixed points never move so your able to correct for any obscurites then your actual GPS receiver is just a way of taking the difference between of when the signal was sent to when it was received then you have a measurement. Multiple that by 3 you get 2d by 4 you 3d keep going and the GPS only gets more more accurate.

I'm a metrologist who worked for the DOD and NASA as well. The career is one most people don't even realize exists but modern society couldn't function without it.

When you buy a pound of beef, how do you know it's a pound? The scale said so but if the scale isn't calibrated properly it could be 3/4ths of a pound and just telling you it's a pound. Same for gasoline and any other product that's sold by weight/volume. When the cop hits you with radar and says it clocked you at 75mph the gun has to be calibrated with tuning forks to know it's accurate.

Metrology and metrologists are always confused for meteorologists but it's a very distinct and specific career field with near endless learning potential. My spell check even marks metrologists as a misspelling which it definitely is not.

It's been kind of getting to me lately, but hearing you, your father, and his coworkers speak on their knowledge of math, technology, and physics alongside the James friggin Webb Telescope with their Southern accents really helped remind me that I'm in good company and we are what we do - not what we sound like. 21:41 ToF (time of flight) sensors are less accurate because light is so fast. Your need a super awesome "stopwatch" in the sensor to get any repeatable results. The more accurate laser displacement sensors (that operate across a broad range) use laser triangulation. Basically, your emitter, detector, and target form a triangle. As the target moves, the angle changes and the returned light sweeps continuously across the detector chip. The sensor your dad used is most likely that type.

Destin, this episode brought back many very interesting memories. I worked as a technician in the Space Simulation Laboratory at Hughes Aircraft (El Segundo, CA) for 19 years. One of the projects I had a hand in was making a model of a new antenna design with photogrammetry. We didn’t have the luxury of using the 0.1 or 0.7 model. We used the flight hardware. Worked as expected but we sweated off several pounds of bullets each time we pushed the ‘go’ button.

So I'm only at the 22 minute mark of the video now, but for months I've been wondering how they manage material distortion due to temperature fluctuation. We're looking at a large sheet here, with comparatively large variations in thickness, that they've sent into space, where the temperature will vary from "warm" on the sunny side, to "cold" on the shaded side. How do they measure it to fit when the complexity of the shrinkage will be hard to know, and the temperature variance will be extreme? Will it eventually rip itself apart? What about the gold coated panels of the mirror - how do they manage their changes to make them fit well?

The tolerances they're working with are insane. I also had no idea that the heat shield layers were being used to radiate heat like heat exchanger and needed to me measured so that someone could model it for Zero G. There's so much information in this video and crazy that it only seems to scratch the surface of complexity of the entire telescope project and impressive that your dad is one of the people working to gather the measurements.

This video alone was worth supporting the channel!!!

You referred to your dad and those he works with as "ordinary people" and I get what you mean; they are ordinary from one perspective. But they're also extraordinary because they take intense pride in their work and make sure to do it right every time. For that, you, your dad and those with whom he works should be applauded because their dedication to precision and putting in the requisite effort and hours is unusual.

Hey Destin, watching these moments you spent with your dad asking things about what he is working on, what does it do, how does it do it all these moment just took me a few months back when i spent some time with my own dad.
I love space, i love science experiments even though i do not understand much of it or the theory or formulas behind it but still i enjoy them like watching magic happening right in front of my eyes, even after explaining all the secrets, the feeling still remains magical. On October 2021 when i finally started to go to work physically after ~2 years, my dad, not at all a science enthusiast, when i got back home from work started asking me questions about space, weather, geography, natural phenomena and also the science behind it. In my 35 years this was the first time my dad asked me something of my interest and listened to my answers (based on my knowledge level) with enthusiasm and awe.
We do not celebrate christmas, as i am from a muslim family, but the christmas of 2021 was very very special to me. On chirstmas day, december 25th 2021, my dad sat with me and watched the live broadcast of the launch of james web space telescope. While watching that, i talked about hubble telescope, comparing to that how gruelling and time consuming and the costly this new jwst was. he also saw the last view of the jwst when it was released and floated away from sight. He asked me when we can see it's first image. i told him it will take around 5 or 6 months as it needs to calibrate all its mirrors, and he became very excited about the prospect and work the engineers put on this for so long even though they need to wait so long to know how successful they were.
but on January 3rd, 2022 my father passed away to heart failure while in Covid ICU. i dont know why i am saying this to you, but your shared moments with your dad kind off jerked my memories of that precious last 3 months and the chrismas night of 2021.
Thank you for your amazing videos and all the respectful greeting to your dad.

At our company, we use lasers for measurements aswell. They are used to calibrate linear encoders of large CNC machines. The lasers accuracy is down to 220nm (but we mostly used just up to 1 µm).
This process can take several days, depending on the amount of axes and the length of each. Measure, enter compensation values, measure again, rinse and repeat, until it's in clients spec. 😁
I've been using the Faro Tracker for like 6 years now.  It's an amazing tool.

Oh man this is so cool. That moment it "clicked" in your discussion with Naveen about the actual purpose of these 5 layers was awesome. I knew the general purpose of the Telescope and I knew overall purpose of the Sunshield but I never fully understood the purpose of all 5 layers. Personally I thought it was was more about redundancy about blocking certain types of light waves. I thought perhaps the first layer was blocking 90% of visible light and then the second layer was blocking another 5% of the deeper penetrating light waves and so on. So then by the time you got to the 4th-5th layer there was no possible way that any form of light could penetrate past that point and you could truly have a light-less environment capable of achieving those freezing cold temperatures. But it was super cool to find out that all those layers are actually designed specifically around transferring the heat out kind of like a heat sync funnel. It finally explains the unique shape of the sunshield not being something aesthetic or simply to save on weight but purpose driven by design around the physics involved. It gives us even more of a reason to admire the craftsmanship involved in this amazing project.

That was awesome, Destin!  My father was a crane operator for the same company for 41 years, and as a child, I was always excited to be able to have him drive us by one of the work locations when they were relatively close by.  My dad helped build hundreds of bridges and roadways around Arizona, and I'm proud of that, but your dad actually got to work on something that might have cost more than all my dad's projects combined, and something that has traveled into space.  There may have been thousands of people that had a hand in the JWST build, but only a dozen or so that actually got to touch and manipulate a piece of actual equipment that is out there right now.  Really special experience indeed.  Thanks for sharing that with us.

Its a genius idea to build a reflective shield to direct the incoming radiation away. But it leaves the question of why the sun-facing layer is darker...

All I can find is that its doped-silicon --- kinda similar to what is done with computer chips. By inserting other atoms (doping) into a silicon crystal, you change various properties.
Probably, the is optimally reflective in the wave length of the sun in space - or in the infra red --- or its optimally emissive of captured heat in the infrared.

Whatever process was used, NASA websites say this doping proces was unique to the specs for this telescope. Cool stuff :D

My grandfather owned a rare massive Celestron C22 telescope he was able to purchase in the 1960’s that he housed in an observatory in beautiful Bolton Landing, NY then be built a theme park based around the scope called Time Town. Celestron only created 10 C22s. Most of which weren’t sold to the general public but more for government/university use. My grandfather’s name is Theodore YUND. Time Town was in operation from 1970-1981. My moms side of the family grew up playing and working at the park as kids and teenagers. All 14 kids. Incredible history especially the story of the C22 and my grandfather being friends with Tom Johnson the founder of Celestron. Werhner Von Braun even visited Time Town park to give a speech. I believe it was about space exploration and rocket science because he was there to dedicate a massive double Apollo astronauts sculpture built by Gene Mundell. There’s some photos of it online if you search Time Town theme park. The story of my grandfathers C22  scope is even more interesting how he obtained and what happened to it. I’m gonna make a video of time town here shortly and I’ll upload the epic pictures for the world to enjoy

As a Surveyor it makes me so happy to see you explain the principles and thought processes I encounter all the time, especially the fact it played a crucial role in aiding the design and manufacturing of the JWT!

Note for people trying to distinguish between metric and imperial conversion: A "Mil" to Destin (And anyone else using imperial measurements) is 0.001 inch, but to someone like me who uses the metric (Far better) system interprets it as "Millimeter" which is 0.001m. the Imperial "Mil" is 0.0254mm (or 0.0000254m). These are far tighter tolerances to what Surveyors will encounter usually.

To answer the question about why the sun-side of the shield is darker has to do with the momentum transfer of photons on the surface. The more reflective the surface, the more force is applied by photons being emitted by the sun. This, in turn, would mean the JWST would have to course correct more often, which could lessen its effectiveness and shorten its mission duration.

A darker side means more absorption of photons, which means less force on the shield, so in turn less fuel is used to remain in the right orbit.

I could be wrong, I'm just working through the physics of the system, and extending what that means to why it would be important to have a darker side facing the sun. If anyone on here worked on the JWST and knows for sure, please fill me in!

Thank you for sharing this Destin. This video spoke to me in ways you couldn't possibly imagine, and it was an honor being able to follow along with you and your Dad on this journey.
My father worked in Aerospace from the late 70's, through to the late 90's. A lot of things he could never talk about (Cold War, Star Wars, etc.), and the few that he could, he shared with me as much as he knew how. One of the very last projects he worked on, was the venerable Delta II Rocket out in Pueblo, Colorado. I still, to this day, have never forgotten the feeling of awe of seeing a space craft up close, and experiencing the smell of a mechanical clean room, and the excitement it filled me with to see raw materials come together to a complex working machine that was going to space. That has been one of, if not the driving force that has led me down a path of engineering my whole life.
I'm 40 now, my Dad long since passed, and watching this brought back a flood of memories from my childhood, and wishing I could go back and take those plant tours again as an adult, and see things with a mind of better understanding. I appreciate that you cherish these memories, and are generous enough to share them with us. Thank you.

I can't even imagine how much went into this project. Much less just the thought process. Being able to spend the time together with your father absolutely is amazing, and share his world is what you will remember forever. Thank you for a great episode.

Data used to be just a nebulous aura that kind of exists alongside the "actual work", but now we are beginning to treat data as an important, respectable, countable thing that is produced and consumed, and has a known cost and value. They have actually built a five layer <del>burrito</del> heat aiming system where they can control how the heat is directed out of the edges of it by reflecting it between the layers until it reaches the edge and radiates out into space. Did someone order the Run On Sentence Bell Grande? I'm hungry. What was I saying? Oh. And the animations in this video helped me totally understand the whole point system. To whomever did those animations: bravo. What a fantastic video. Every time I learn something new about Webb, I think it's the most incredible thing I've ever heard but then it always happens again. It's incredible that a material that thin can be so robust. Mr. Sandlin is just an awesome teacher. I can clearly see where Destin gets it. Again, what an awesome video.

We used a dis-similar location system in Surgery, for Head, Neck & Joint, some years ago. Introducing it was a TRIAL.
The patient would get scanned with balls attached to their skin, and the instruments would have a scaffold with more of the balls attached. A computer with a set of FLIR CAMERAS above the surgical suite referenced everything LIVE and assisted the surgeon when aligning their cuts.
It was especially helpful in Brain Tumor Surgery. Combining fMRI, Cat Scans, and visual cues, saved brain matter, and lives.
